prompt: <description>Part 1: Construct a rectangular prism with a curved top and flat bottom. The first part of our CAD model is a rectangular prism with a curved top and flat bottom. Begin by creating a new coordinate system with the given Euler angles and translation vector. Create a sketch on the X-Y plane of the new coordinate system. In the sketch, draw a rectangle with the following vertices: (0, 0), (0.75, 0), (0.75, 0.0625), (0.5677, 0.0625), (0.5677, 0.25), (0.5053, 0.253), (0.2442, 0.25), (0.1817, 0.25), (0.1817, 0.0625), and (0, 0.0625). The rectangle consists of nine line segments, as described above. After creating the rectangle, add an arc to the sketch that starts at the point (0.5053, 0.253) and ends at the point (0.2442, 0.25), with the midpoint at (0.3762, 0.121). Close the loop by connecting the endpoint of the arc to the starting point of the rectangle. Now, scale the sketch by a factor of 0.75 using the sketch_scale parameter. Additionally, transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch by applying the given rotation and translation vectors of the coordinate system. Extrude the sketch into a 3D model with a depth of 0.2812 units toward the positive Z-axis. Specify a sketch scale of 0.75. This completes the first part. Part 2: Create a hole in the bracket Next, we'll create a circular hole in the bracket. Begin by setting up a new coordinate system with the given Euler angles and translation vector. Create a sketch on the X-Y plane of the new coordinate system. Draw a circle with a center at (0.0312, 0.0312) and a radius of 0.0312 units. This circle is offset from the origin by the specified translation vector. Transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch by applying the given rotation and translation vectors of the coordinate system. Cut the coordinating cylindrical space out of the bracket using the specified extrusion depths. This marks the completion of the second part. Part 3: Add threading to the hole The final part involves creating a threaded hole in the bracket. Begin by configuring a new coordinate system that matches the previous coordinate system. Create a sketch on the X-Y plane of the new coordinate system. Draw a circle with a center at (0.0312, 0.0312) and a radius of 0.0312 units. This circle is offset from the origin by the specified translation vector. Transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch by applying the same rotation and translation vectors of the coordinate system. Once again, cut the coordinating cylindrical space out, while using the specified extrusion depths to create a threaded hole in the bracket. This marks the finishing touches on the final part of our CAD model.</description>
